author: p_bitfly
content: just some input on what we see from a miners perspective after eip 1559 went live: most of the fee rewards miners receive during demand spikes (like nft drops) are from the initial demand upramp (time it takes for the base fee to ramp up). this causes high fee reward periods to become very short, usually only a few blocks long. given the short time span of the base fee upramp this favors large mining pools (and staking pools in the future) as they have a higher chance of hitting those high rewards blocks compared to small pools. this will further increase centralization as miners will chose larger pools because of their more predictable income (this is the case already, but it is now amplified by the shortness of the reward spikes). adjusting the base fee adjustment so that is increases with a slower rate will make distribution of fees during demand spike much more wider (at the cost of less fee being burned)

content:
thanks for sharing <@!471975503859810316> !

Re: "adjusting the base fee adjustment so that is increases with a slower rate will make distribution of fees during demand spike much more wider (at the cost of less fee being burned)", I believe this is something that some researchers are looking into. We discussed it on ACD and there was no objection to change the upramp/downramp speed if we could show data for what a better one would be.

author: p_bitfly
content: yes, if the base fee adjustment would be a bit less responsive it would ensure a broader distribution of tx fee rewards during spikes

author: sky.cactus
content: The goal needs to be to improve the user experience, not enrich miners more or spread fees out more evenly to miners.

author: p_bitfly
content: but the goal should also be not to further reduce decentralization of miners/stakers by benefiting large entities

author: pietjepuk
content: I'd much rather look into the AMM curve type of base fee, instead of finicking around with these details to make miners or staking pools richer

author: p_bitfly
content: there are lots of ways how to adjust the base fee, but the current mechanism increases variance of mining/staking rewards (compared to pre-1559 times). increased variance will benefit large pools/stakers vs. small ones

author: p_bitfly
content: previously mining revenue was more or less on par among most of the miners (https://www.etherchain.org/miner). after eip 1559 we started to see sometimes huge outliers in daily revenue for some miners (caused by them hitting block during the base fee onramp)

author: p_bitfly
content: large pools tend to hit those onramps more often compared to small pools (as they are quite short)

author: p_bitfly
content: causing higher revenue variance for small miners

author: pietjepuk
content: And slower rising base fee gives rise to fee-dominated chain type of attacks (longer and more profitable to reorg)

author: p_bitfly
content: and large will give rise to 51% attacks as pools get too big

author: p_bitfly
content: as miners tend to favor consistent income vs. high variance

author: pietjepuk
content: So either way it's risky, and seems that we need something else. Adjusting the base fee rate of increase is not going to help

author: p_bitfly
content: it is just an observation we had during the last month that you may or may not take as input in futher developing the fee market
